content: hey guys let's good see you again we're on Episode seven of black magic
craft and today we are making at work we're making sweet looking spider egg
nest web things Avenel what do you want from me there spider eggs they're gross
they look cool it's a fun little project if you need something to scare or entice
your players if your groups like mine you have a barbarian that pokes
everything anyway this is just a quick easy fun project and it actually spawned
from materials there's something that I would see on an almost daily basis and
every time I saw it I would think oh that would make awesome webs I finally
got around to testing it out and turns out to work pretty good what's the magic
component I'll show you Steve Steve has me the thing come on hey
wake up just ask him to forget thick aah one sec sorry that's Steve he's new here
he's an intern he's not very smart but he's all that I can afford anyway
the magic web ingredient dryer sheets yep whenever I emptied the dryer as long
as I've been crafting I looked at these and go that would make an awesome web so
I decided to finally try it out and at first you know what it didn't actually
work super great I tried a watered-down PVA glue mixture to stiffen it up but it
just filled all the little holes the surface tension was too high and it was
just a mess but I did in the end find a way
to make it look really good and attach it and yeah I'm really happy with the
results so let's go and take a look at how we made them you're going to start
off by cutting out some bases lately I've been using these samples from
formica countertops you can pick them up at the hardware store for free they're
nice because they're really stiff they're thin and they don't get a lot of
warpage you're going to need some kind of stones for the eggs to sit between
and the web to go over I'm just using some scrap insulation foam to carve
something up obviously you can use real stones but right now it's winter and all
the stones are buried under snow plus I like carving out of styrofoam you're
happy with whatever you're using you want to cover your whole base in PVA
glue and place your stones here same as a lot of the other projects just grab
some of the construction sand sprinkle it all over to give it some texture need
the eggs at the dollar store I came across these little styrofoam beads I
guess you'd call them don't know what they're actually intended for but when I
saw him I thought they would make awesome eggs so I took some PVA glue
grabbed a handful of these little styrofoam pellets and started mixing him
up I wanted to make sure that they were completely covered because later I'm
going to be spray-painting this and I didn't want them to melt I'm just adding
a base of PVA to set the little pellets in I actually think this step might have
been unnecessary or if not I could have got away with using a lot less I found
that as I was placing them they're starting to sink so I would recommend
using a little bit less glue if you can't find these little styrofoam
pellets at your dollar store you could use anything really that's about the
same size and is round plastic beads would obviously work great
heck even certain little bee from the bulk bin would work so once
that glue dries which takes quite a long time I left it overnight I spray-painted
the whole thing black out to painting I decided that painting the actual eggs
first would be the smartest step because building up the white actually took
several coats from the black for this reason I used a more creamy white and a
blow-dryer in between so that I could quickly get them coated with multiple
coats once I was happy with the white coverage I decided to mix up a little
bit of a wash to get in the crevices of the eggs make them look a little bit
more gnarly well I just took some water a little bit of a bright green and some
black to darken it up and mixed it's super super watery I probably should
have put in some soap or flow aid of some sort it was just keeping it simple
I'm sure you guys that paint a lot of miniatures have a selection of washes on
hand or have some really good techniques for making your own I don't do a lot of
painting with washes because I don't make miniatures for my gameplay I use
paper minis so everything I'm painting is terrain and usually it doesn't
require something like a wash I just do dry brushing but here I thought with
these eggs it would spice it up a little bit make it look a little bit more
interesting once I was happy with the wash and it had completely dried I came
back in with a true bright white and just hit the tops of the eggs to give it
a bit more contrast see here the Aged are starting to look
kind of icky which is what we want I then just went around quickly with some
black and cut in all the over brush white before moving on to painting of
the gray fortunately my phone ran out of memory and I had it on silent so I
didn't realize while recording and I missed all the painting I'm not too
worried about it though you know all the techniques are the same that we used on
the modular tiles in episode 1 and obviously you guys will be using
whatever techniques you use on your own terrain and tiles and you're going to
want to match it to that we want to make sure that this pile of
eggs looks real slimy and gross so grab some clear nail polish and slop it on
the surface get it all over the rocks everywhere that the spider would have
spat out its web and eggs maybe two or three coats if you want it to look extra
slimy now the fun part the spiderwebs take a used dryer sheet one it's less
wasteful than a new one and it will actually work better now start tearing
it apart into a more workable size you want those kind of frayed edges you want
to pull it apart get some holes in it and make it look a lot less uniformed
and more natural then just place it on your piece and kind of get a feel for
how you're going to want it to sit you're going to want to see where you
want glue and where you don't the way we're attaching this is with the Hobby
tack from woodland Scenic's it's the same stuff you would use if you
were flocking trees basically you want to paint it on everywhere you want the
web to stick avoiding the places that you don't it's going to go on white but
it will dry clear in about 15 minutes and get real tacky and then you can go
and carefully place your webs on top and just kind of get it sitting to a
point where you're happy with it trying to make sure it looks kind of realistic
and make sure it's really stuck down on the edges because then you want to start
ripping off the excess don't cut it rip it off that'll make it look even better
once you have a small amount left over then you can snip that off with the
scissors for something that comes out of the
laundry room garbage can I think these look fantastic for some added protection
you can give it a quick coat of Mod Podge or some other kind of acrylic
sealer to lock everything in place alright guys I hope you enjoyed this
tutorial as always if you haven't already please hit subscribe hit like on
the video and most importantly leave me a comment let me know what you thought
maybe what you do differently and if there's any projects that you'd like to
see you try to tackle and do my spin on let me know in the comments I'm making a
list of future videos and every time someone asks for something what was on
the list okay until next time
